Natalia,

IMO testing each exception in a method of its own is a good way to
handle it. That way you have many small test methods which make it
easier for the reader of the test class to understand your tests. 
Personally, I don't consider it a good idea to use the same OUT (object
under test) for provoking different exceptions in a sequence since clean
recovery from exceptions is often problematic and you might run into
subtle variations of your behaviour. 
However, sometimes it is crucial to test that another exception does (or
does not) occur after a first one has already been thrown (and handled
somehow). In that case
do in your test what you would do with your first exception in client
code, e.g. catch and ignore it. Then provoke the second exception and
check that it's being thrown.

Johannes

> Thanks in advanced!
> Natalia
